options: Time between the end of the Q wave and the start of the T wave
Time between the start of the Q wave and the end of the T wave
Time between the end of the QRS waveform and the start of the T wave
Time between the end of the Q wave and the end of the T wave
Time between the start of the Q wave and the start of the T wave
questions: You are reviewing a 56-year-old man who has recently been successfully cardioverted following an episode of ventricular tachycardia. He had recently been treated with a course of erythromycin. You are interested to see if he has an underlying prolonged QT interval. What is the most appropriate way to measure the QT interval on the ECG?
question: You are reviewing a 56-year-old man who has recently been successfully cardioverted following an episode of ventricular tachycardia. He had recently been treated with a course of erythromycin. You are interested to see if he has an underlying prolonged QT interval. What is the most appropriate way to measure the QT interval on the ECG?
title: Long QT syndrome
body:
Long QT syndrome (LQTS) is an inherited condition associated with delayed repolarization of the ventricles. It is important to recognise as it may lead to ventricular tachycardia/torsade de pointes and can therefore cause collapse/sudden death. The most common variants of LQTS (LQT1 & LQT2) are caused by defects in the alpha subunit of the slow delayed rectifier potassium channel. A normal corrected QT interval is less than 430 ms in males and 450 ms in females.

Causes of a prolonged QT interval:

CongenitalDrugs*Other
  • Jervell-Lange-Nielsen syndrome (includes deafness and is due to an abnormal potassium channel)
  • Romano-Ward syndrome (no deafness)
  • amiodarone, sotalol, class 1a antiarrhythmic drugs
  • tricyclic antidepressants, selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (especially citalopram)
  • methadone
  • chloroquine
  • terfenadine**
  • erythromycin
  • haloperidol
  • ondanestron
  • electrolyte: hypocalcaemia, hypokalaemia, hypomagnesaemia
  • acute myocardial infarction
  • myocarditis
  • hypothermia
  • subarachnoid haemorrhage

    • Features
    • may be picked up on routine ECG or following family screening
    • Long QT1 - usually associated with exertional syncope, often swimming
    • Long QT2 - often associated with syncope occurring following emotional stress, exercise or auditory stimuli
    • Long QT3 - events often occur at night or at rest
    • sudden cardiac death

    Management
    • avoid drugs which prolong the QT interval and other precipitants if appropriate (e.g. Strenuous exercise)
    • beta-blockers***
    • implantable cardioverter defibrillators in high risk cases

    *the usual mechanism by which drugs prolong the QT interval is blockage of potassium channels. See the link for more details

    **a non-sedating antihistamine and classic cause of prolonged QT in a patient, especially if also taking P450 enzyme inhibitor, e.g. Patient with a cold takes terfenadine and erythromycin at the same time

    ***note sotalol may exacerbate long QT syndrome
concept: QT interval: Time between the start of the Q wave and the end of the T wave
links:
Pharmacolgy Review239
2010 Drug-Induced Long QT syndrome


Life in the Fast Lane2911
QT Interval and Long QT syndrome
media:
Advanced EKGs - The QT Interval and Long QT Syndrome
Strong Medicine - YouTube63
 
Long QT syndrome & torsade de pointes
Osmosis - YouTube34

2416.concept_text: Citalopram is associated with dose-dependent QT interval prolongation

3335.concept_text: Hypokalaemia can lead to long QT syndrome

7889.concept_text: Erythromycin can cause a prolonged QT interval

8125.concept_text: A long QT interval - myocardial ischaemia

questions:
A 52-year-old man presents to his GP with vertigo and earache. He reports feeling that the room is spinning over the past 2 days. On examination, there is a left facial droop, the patient is unable to lift his left eyebrow, along with a vesicular rash around the left ear, the tympanic membrane looks healthy with a preserved cone of light. His heart rate is 78bpm, blood pressure is 134/84mmHg and temperature is 37.2ºC. He has a past medical history of type II diabetes mellitus for which he takes metformin.

What is the most appropriate treatment to commence?
notes:
This man has presented with vertigo, ear pain, facial palsy, and a vesicular rash which points toward Ramsay Hunt syndrome. Ramsay Hunt syndrome (herpes zoster oticus) is a herpes zoster infection of the facial nerve that could present with facial paralysis, vesicular rash around the ear, and hearing and vestibular symptoms. Treatment is with pain management and both aciclovir and corticosteroids.

Aciclovir is incorrect. Aciclovir is an antiviral that is used to treat herpes simplex and herpes zoster viral infections; using aciclovir alone to treat Ramsay-Hunt syndrome would not be sufficient as using prednisolone along with aciclovir is recommended by NICE guidance.

Flucloxacillin is incorrect. Flucloxacillin is an antibiotic used to treat infections such as cellulitis, a skin infection that presents with hot, red, and tender skin. This man has a vesicular rash which makes cellulitis unlikely.

Prednisolone is incorrect. Prednisolone has anti-inflammatory properties and is used to reduce inflammation in the facial nerve. However, there is evidence that using aciclovir along with prednisolone improves the outcome and provides a higher recovery rate than using prednisolone alone.

Prochlorperazine is incorrect. It would be helpful to control the vertigo symptoms and could be prescribed for this man for symptomatic relief. However, this patient needs an antiviral and prednisolone as he is having Ramsay Hunt syndrome.

Prochlorperazine is incorrect. It would be helpful to control the vertigo symptoms and could be prescribed for this man for symptomatic relief. However, this patient needs an antiviral and prednisolone as he is having Ramsay Hunt syndrome.
title: Ramsay Hunt syndrome
body:
Ramsay Hunt syndrome (herpes zoster oticus) is caused by the reactivation of the varicella zoster virus in the geniculate ganglion of the seventh cranial nerve.

Features
  • auricular pain is often the first feature
  • facial nerve palsy
  • vesicular rash around the ear
  • other features include vertigo and tinnitus

Management
  • oral aciclovir and corticosteroids are usually given
concept: Treatment of Ramsay Hunt syndrome consists of oral aciclovir and corticosteroids
media:
Varicella zoster virus
Osmosis - YouTube10

10825.concept_text: Treatment of Ramsay Hunt syndrome consists of oral aciclovir and corticosteroids

options: Make a routine referral to the paediatric specialist
Ask the mother to bring back her son for review in 3 months
Ask the mother to bring back her son for review in 6 weeks
Reassure her that this is part of normal development
Make a urgent referral to the paediatric specialist
questions:
A worried mother comes to the GP surgery with her son who is 18 months old. She is concerned that he is still unable to combine two words. He is only able to say single words. She has no concern over other aspects of his development. There is no family history of note.

What would be your initial step in management?
notes:
Children should be able to combine two words by 2 years. The child is developing normally.

There is no need to refer to the paediatric specialist at this stage.

There is no need to ask for a review in 6 weeks or 3 months at this stage.
question:

title: Developmental milestones: speech and hearing
body:
The table below summarises the major speech and hearing developmental milestones

AgeMilestone
3 monthsQuietens to parents voice
Turns towards sound
Squeals
6 monthsDouble syllables 'adah', 'erleh'
9 monthsSays 'mama' and 'dada'
Understands 'no'
12 monthsKnows and responds to own name
12-15 monthsKnows about 2-6 words (Refer at 18 months)
Understands simple commands - 'give it to mummy'
2 yearsCombine two words
Points to parts of the body
2½ yearsVocabulary of 200 words
3 yearsTalks in short sentences (e.g. 3-5 words)
Asks 'what' and 'who' questions
Identifies colours
Counts to 10 (little appreciation of numbers though)
4 yearsAsks 'why', 'when' and 'how' questions
concept: Children should be able to combine two words by 2 years
links:
MRCPCH Clinical revision2316
Summary of developmental schedule

questions: A 49-year-old man presents to the GP with a year history of twitching and cramps in his legs. He tells you that he has had problems recently with swallowing both liquids and food. He has no past medical history. On examination you note hypophonia and tongue fasciculations. . Given these signs, which of the following conditions should be considered for further investigation?
notes: Tongue fasciculations represent one of the bulbar signs of motor neuron disease. Although benign fasciculation syndrome is a common cause of tongue fasciculations, the rest of the history points to something more sinister. The rest of the conditions are red herrings.
question: A 49-year-old man presents to the GP with a year history of twitching and cramps in his legs. He tells you that he has had problems recently with swallowing both liquids and food. He has no past medical history. On examination you note hypophonia and tongue fasciculations. . Given these signs, which of the following conditions should be considered for further investigation?
question_notes: Tongue fasciculations represent one of the bulbar signs of motor neuron disease. Although benign fasciculation syndrome is a common cause of tongue fasciculations, the rest of the history points to something more sinister. The rest of the conditions are red herrings.
title: Motor neuron disease: features
body:
Motor neuron disease is a neurological condition of unknown cause which can present with both upper and lower motor neuron signs. It rarely presents before 40 years and various patterns of disease are recognised including amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS), progressive muscular atrophy and bulbar palsy.

There are a number of clues which point towards a diagnosis of motor neuron disease:
  • asymmetric limb weakness is the most common presentation of ALS
  • the mixture of lower motor neuron and upper motor neuron signs
  • wasting of the small hand muscles/tibialis anterior is common
  • fasciculations
  • the absence of sensory signs/symptoms
    • vague sensory symptoms may occur early in the disease (e.g. limb pain) but 'never' sensory signs

Other features
  • doesn't affect external ocular muscles
  • no cerebellar signs
  • abdominal reflexes are usually preserved and sphincter dysfunction if present is a late feature

The diagnosis of motor neuron disease is clinical, but nerve conduction studies will show normal motor conduction and can help exclude a neuropathy. Electromyography shows a reduced number of action potentials with increased amplitude. MRI is usually performed to exclude the differential diagnosis of cervical cord compression and myelopathy
concept: Tongue fasciculations are one of the signs of bulbar onset motor neuron disease
links:
Royal College of Physicians1717
Motor neuron disease: diagnostic pitfalls


Postgraduate Medical Journal1614
Review of MND
media:
Motor neuron disease
Zero To Finals - YouTube81

8779.concept_text: Eye movements are typically spared in motor neurone disease

questions: A 4-year-old boy is noted to have macrocephaly and learning difficulties. What is the most likely diagnosis?
notes:
The correct answer is Fragile X. Fragile X syndrome is a genetic disorder which often presents with macrocephaly, prominent ears and jaw, learning difficulties and behavioural problems. It is the most common inherited cause of intellectual disability in boys. The condition is due to an expansion of a CGG repeat on the X chromosome which leads to hypermethylation and reduced expression of the FMR1 gene.

Patau syndrome (Trisomy 13) is incorrect as it typically presents with severe congenital malformations including microcephaly (not macrocephaly), cleft lip/palate, polydactyly, cardiac defects and severe intellectual disability. Most affected individuals do not survive beyond infancy due to multiple organ system involvement.

Pierre-Robin syndrome is also incorrect. This condition features a triad of micrognathia (small lower jaw), glossoptosis (downward displacement or retraction of the tongue) and airway obstruction, but macrocephaly and learning difficulties are not typical presentations.

Edward's syndrome (Trisomy 18) is another incorrect option. This condition presents with growth retardation, severe intellectual disability, microcephaly, overlapping fingers, rocker-bottom feet, congenital heart disease and other anomalies. Again, macrocephaly would not be expected in this syndrome.

Lastly, William's syndrome, although associated with learning difficulties and distinctive facial features such as a broad forehead, short nose with a broad tip and full cheeks does not usually present with macrocephaly but rather may present with mild microcephaly or normal head circumference.

In summary, while all these conditions can lead to learning difficulties in children they have distinct clinical presentations that differentiate them from each other. In this case scenario presented above Fragile X syndrome fits the best given the combination of macrocephaly and learning difficulties.

title: Childhood syndromes
body:
Below is a list of common features of selected childhood syndromes

SyndromeKey features
Patau syndrome (trisomy 13)
Microcephalic, small eyes
Cleft lip/palate
Polydactyly
Scalp lesions
Edward's syndrome (trisomy 18)
Micrognathia
Low-set ears
Rocker bottom feet
Overlapping of fingers
Fragile X
Learning difficulties
Macrocephaly
Long face
Large ears
Macro-orchidism
Noonan syndrome
Webbed neck
Pectus excavatum
Short stature
Pulmonary stenosis
Pierre-Robin syndrome*
Micrognathia
Posterior displacement of the tongue (may result in upper airway obstruction)
Cleft palate
Prader-Willi syndrome
Hypotonia
Hypogonadism
Obesity
William's syndrome
Short stature
Learning difficulties
Friendly, extrovert personality
Transient neonatal hypercalcaemia
Supravalvular aortic stenosis
Cri du chat syndrome (chromosome 5p deletion syndrome)Characteristic cry (hence the name) due to larynx and neurological problems
Feeding difficulties and poor weight gain
Learning difficulties
Microcephaly and micrognathism
Hypertelorism

*this condition has many similarities with Treacher-Collins syndrome. One of the key differences is that Treacher-Collins syndrome is autosomal dominant so there is usually a family history of similar problems

questions:
A 23-year-old woman presents to the GP clinic with intermittently painful fingers. It happens every few days and she describes her fingers becoming pale, painful and numb. After a few minutes, they become pink and then go back to normal. This is distressing her immensely and she would like to commence treatment. She is a smoker of 15 cigarettes daily, has a 5-pack-year history and has no other medical issues and no other significant symptoms.

What is the most appropriate next step?
notes:
This is a young woman with Raynaud's disease. She should be given non-pharmacological advice such as staying warm, stopping smoking, wearing gloves and avoiding the cold. This is often sufficient to control symptoms. However, given her significant distress, it would be appropriate to commence a first-line pharmacological option which in this case would be a dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker such as nifedipine.

Intravenous epoprostenol is an option for this condition, however, it is definitely not the first line. It would involve potential adverse effects which include the risk of sepsis from intravenous access and hypotension, flushing, nausea, vomiting and headache from the medication. Oral nifedipine would be much more appropriate to trial initially.

Diltiazem is a non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker with activity in the gut and heart. It can therefore cause bradycardia and constipation and should be avoided in this case where there is an effective and safer alternative such as nifedipine.

Metoprolol is a beta-blocker and this class of medication should be avoided in this patient's condition. This is because they reduce the heart rate by inhibiting cardiac adrenergic receptors which in turn reduces blood pressure and peripheral perfusion.

Propranolol is another beta-blocker that should be avoided. Beta-blockers are actually implicated in Raynaud's phenomenon and this should be sought as a possible cause in patients presenting with this condition.

title: Raynaud's phenomenon
body:
Raynaud's phenomenon is characterised by an exaggerated vasoconstrictive response of the digital arteries and cutaneous arteriole to the cold or emotional stress. It may be primary (Raynaud's disease) or secondary (Raynaud's phenomenon).

Raynaud's disease typically presents in young women (e.g. 30 years old) with bilateral symptoms.

Secondary causes of Raynaud's phenomenon
  • connective tissue disorders
    • scleroderma (most common)
    • rheumatoid arthritis
    • systemic lupus erythematosus
  • leukaemia
  • type I cryoglobulinaemia, cold agglutinins
  • use of vibrating tools
  • drugs: oral contraceptive pill, ergot
  • cervical rib

Factors suggesting underlying connective tissue disease
  • onset after 40 years
  • unilateral symptoms
  • rashes
  • presence of autoantibodies
  • features which may suggest rheumatoid arthritis or SLE, for example arthritis or recurrent miscarriages
  • digital ulcers, calcinosis
  • very rarely: chilblains

Management
  • all patients with suspected secondary Raynaud's phenomenon should be referred to secondary care
  • first-line: calcium channel blockers e.g. nifedipine
  • IV prostacyclin (epoprostenol) infusions: effects may last several weeks/months
concept: Nifedipine is a pharmacological option for Raynaud's phenomenon
links:
Arthritis Research Council (ARC)68
ARC Raynaud's Patient Info
media:
Raynaud's phenomenon
Armando Hasudungan - YouTube20
 
Raynaud's phenomenon
Townsend Teaching - YouTube00

312.concept_text: Raynaud's disease (i.e. primary) presents in young women with bilateral symptoms

8487.concept_text: Nifedipine is a pharmacological option for Raynaud's phenomenon

questions:
A 25-year-old female currently under investigation for secondary amenorrhoea presents with jaundiced sclera. On examination spider naevi are present along with tender hepatomegaly. Blood tests show:

Hb11.6 g/dl
Plt145 * 109/l
WCC6.4 * 109/l
 
Albumin33 g/l
Bilirubin112 µmol/l
ALT845 iu/l

What is the most likely diagnosis?
notes:
Autoimmune hepatitis is the correct diagnosis in this case. The presentation strongly suggests autoimmune hepatitis (AIH), which typically affects young females and can present with amenorrhoea due to its association with other autoimmune conditions affecting the endocrine system. The blood results show a hepatitic picture with markedly elevated ALT (845 iu/l) and raised bilirubin (112 µmol/l), along with clinical signs of chronic liver disease (spider naevi). The combination of these features in a young female is highly characteristic of AIH.

Haemochromatosis is incorrect because it typically presents in middle-aged males. While it can cause amenorrhoea in females, this usually occurs later in the disease course. Additionally, haemochromatosis typically presents with normal liver enzymes until advanced disease, unlike the marked ALT elevation seen here.

Wilson's disease, while it can present in young adults with liver dysfunction, typically presents earlier (usually before age 20). While it remains a consideration in young patients with liver disease, the combination of amenorrhoea and autoimmune features makes AIH more likely. Wilson's disease would also typically present with neurological symptoms and Kayser-Fleischer rings.

Primary biliary cirrhosis (now termed primary biliary cholangitis) typically affects middle-aged females (40-60 years). While it can cause amenorrhoea, the ALT pattern would typically be less marked, with a more cholestatic picture. The patient's age makes this diagnosis less likely.

Primary sclerosing cholangitis is incorrect as it predominantly affects males and is strongly associated with inflammatory bowel disease. The biochemical pattern would typically be more cholestatic rather than hepatitic, and the age and gender profile does not fit with this diagnosis.

Primary sclerosing cholangitis is incorrect as it predominantly affects males and is strongly associated with inflammatory bowel disease. The biochemical pattern would typically be more cholestatic rather than hepatitic, and the age and gender profile does not fit with this diagnosis.
title: Autoimmune hepatitis
body:
Autoimmune hepatitis is condition of unknown aetiology which is most commonly seen in young females. Recognised associations include other autoimmune disorders, hypergammaglobulinaemia and HLA B8, DR3. Three types of autoimmune hepatitis have been characterised according to the types of circulating antibodies present

Type IType IIType III
Anti-nuclear antibodies (ANA) and/or anti-smooth muscle antibodies (SMA)

Affects both adults and children
Anti-liver/kidney microsomal type 1 antibodies (LKM1)

Affects children only
Soluble liver-kidney antigen

Affects adults in middle-age

Features
  • may present with signs of chronic liver disease
  • acute hepatitis: fever, jaundice etc (only 25% present in this way)
  • amenorrhoea (common)
  • ANA/SMA/LKM1 antibodies, raised IgG levels
  • liver biopsy: inflammation extending beyond limiting plate 'piecemeal necrosis', bridging necrosis

Management
  • steroids, other immunosuppressants e.g. azathioprine
  • liver transplantation
media:
Autoimmune hepatitis
Medicosis Perfectionalis - YouTube10
 
Autoimmune hepatitis
Zero To Finals - YouTube00
 
Autoimmune hepatitis
Armando Hasudungan - YouTube11
 
Autoimmune hepatitis

options: Increase dietary intake of folate only
Folic acid 5mg daily, continue until end of 1st trimester
Folic acid 5mg daily, continue until end of pregnancy
Folic acid 400mcg daily, continue until end of 1st trimester
Folic acid 400mcg daily, continue until end of pregnancy
questions:
A 22-year-old woman telephones her GP for a referral to antenatal care. She has been trying to conceive for the past year and has now tested positive for pregnancy. Her last menstrual period (LMP) was 5 weeks ago, prompting her to take a pregnancy test. She is medically well with no underlying health conditions, does not smoke, and does not drink alcohol. The patient has a BMI of 34 kg/m².

What is the recommended folic acid intake for this patient?
notes:
Folic acid intake is important in the 1st trimester of pregnancy to help prevent neural tube defects (NTD). For most pregnant patients, 400mcg daily in the first 12 weeks of pregnancy should prove sufficient. However, patients with a BMI of more than 30 kg/m² should be provided with 5mg daily for the first 12 weeks of pregnancy.

In addition to patients with a BMI of more than 30 kg/m², folic acid should also be prescribed at a 5mg daily dose for those with diabetes, sickle cell disease (SCD), thalassaemia trait, coeliac disease, on anti-epileptic medication, personal or family history of NTD, or who have previously given birth to a baby with an NTD. Ideally, folic acid should be commenced whilst trying to conceive as this will further minimise NTD risk.

Alongside folic acid, NICE recommend all pregnant patients take vitamin D 10mcg (400 units) daily. This should be continued throughout the duration of their entire pregnancy.
question:
A 22-year-old woman telephones her GP for a referral to antenatal care. She has been trying to conceive for the past year and has now tested positive for pregnancy. Her last menstrual period (LMP) was 5 weeks ago, prompting her to take a pregnancy test. She is medically well with no underlying health conditions, does not smoke, and does not drink alcohol. The patient has a BMI of 34 kg/m².

What is the recommended folic acid intake for this patient?
question_notes:
Folic acid intake is important in the 1st trimester of pregnancy to help prevent neural tube defects (NTD). For most pregnant patients, 400mcg daily in the first 12 weeks of pregnancy should prove sufficient. However, patients with a BMI of more than 30 kg/m² should be provided with 5mg daily for the first 12 weeks of pregnancy.

In addition to patients with a BMI of more than 30 kg/m², folic acid should also be prescribed at a 5mg daily dose for those with diabetes, sickle cell disease (SCD), thalassaemia trait, coeliac disease, on anti-epileptic medication, personal or family history of NTD, or who have previously given birth to a baby with an NTD. Ideally, folic acid should be commenced whilst trying to conceive as this will further minimise NTD risk.

Alongside folic acid, NICE recommend all pregnant patients take vitamin D 10mcg (400 units) daily. This should be continued throughout the duration of their entire pregnancy.
title: Pregnancy: obesity
body:
Obese women, and their unborn children, are at an increased risk of a number of complications during pregnancy and labour. Obesity is usually defined as a body mass index (BMI) >= 30 kg/m² at the first antenatal visit.

Maternal risks
  • miscarriage
  • venous thromboembolism
  • gestational diabetes
  • pre-eclampsia
  • dysfunctional labour, induced labour
  • postpartum haemorrhage
  • wound infections

There is also a higher caesarean section rate.

Fetal risks
  • congenital anomaly
  • prematurity
  • macrosomia
  • stillbirth
  • increased risk of developing obesity and metabolic disorders in childhood
  • neonatal death

With respect to weight loss, NICE state:


Explain to women with a BMI of 30 or more at the booking appointment how this poses a risk, both to their health and the health of the unborn child. Explain that they should not try to reduce this risk by dieting while pregnant and that the risk will be managed by the health professionals caring for them during their pregnancy

Management
  • obese women should take 5mg of folic acid, rather than 400mcg
  • all obese women should be screened for gestational diabetes with an oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT) at 24-28 weeks
  • if the BMI >= 35 kg/m² women should give birth in a consultant-led obstetric unit
  • if the BMI >= 40 kg/m² should have an antenatal consultation with an obstetric anaesthetist and a plan made
concept: Pregnant women with a BMI >= 30 kg/m²  should receive 5 mg folic acid daily until the 13th week of pregnancy
links:
CMACE/RCOG Joint Guideline11
Management of Women with Obesity in Pregnancy


NICE10
2010 Weight management before, during and after pregnancy

questions: A 55 year old gentleman presents with a new skin lesion to the forehead.  On examination there is a 6mm diameter scaly patch which does not appear indurated or ulcerated.  He works as a gardener.  He has a past medical history of type 1 diabetes and renal transplant, and his medications include insulin, aspirin, simvastatin, and tacrolimus.  What is the most appropriate course of action?
notes:
Although this lesion may turn out to be a simple actinic keratosis, squamous cell carcinomas are more common in patients who are immunosuppressed, and may present atypically and grow rapidly. NICE therefore advises all patients who have received organ transplants are referred urgently to a dermatologist if they present with any new or growing skin lesions.

Source: NICE Referral guidelines for suspected cancer
http://www.nice.org.uk/guidance/cg27/chapter/1-recommendations

He works as a gardener.  He has a past medical history of type 1 diabetes and renal transplant, and his medications include insulin, aspirin, simvastatin, and tacrolimus.  What is the most appropriate course of action?
question_notes:
Although this lesion may turn out to be a simple actinic keratosis, squamous cell carcinomas are more common in patients who are immunosuppressed, and may present atypically and grow rapidly. NICE therefore advises all patients who have received organ transplants are referred urgently to a dermatologist if they present with any new or growing skin lesions.

Source: NICE Referral guidelines for suspected cancer
http://www.nice.org.uk/guidance/cg27/chapter/1-recommendations
title: Squamous cell carcinoma of the skin
body:
Squamous cell carcinoma is a common variant of skin cancer. Metastases are rare but may occur in 2-5% of patients.

Risk factors include:
  • excessive exposure to sunlight / psoralen UVA therapy
  • actinic keratoses and Bowen's disease
  • immunosuppression e.g. following renal transplant, HIV
  • smoking
  • long-standing leg ulcers (Marjolin's ulcer)
  • genetic conditions e.g. xeroderma pigmentosum, oculocutaneous albinism

Features
  • typically on sun-exposed sites such as the head and neck or dorsum of the hands and arms
  • rapidly expanding painless, ulcerate nodules
  • may have a cauliflower-like appearance
  • there may be areas of bleeding

Image gallery


Treatment

Surgical excision with 4mm margins if lesion <20mm in diameter. If tumour >20mm then margins should be 6mm. Mohs micrographic surgery may be used in high-risk patients and in cosmetically important sites.

Prognosis

Good PrognosisPoor prognosis
Well differentiated tumoursPoorly differentiated tumours
<20mm diameter>20mm in diameter
<2mm deep>4mm deep
No associated diseasesImmunosupression for whatever reason
links:
DermNet NZ255
Squamous cell carcinoma
media:
Skin cancers
Osmosis - YouTube10

2441.concept_text: Renal transplant patients - skin cancer (particularly squamous cell) is the most common malignancy secondary to immunosuppression

questions:
A 48-year-old man attends his GP appointment after finding a new lump in his scrotum. This was noticed a week ago during self-examination whilst in the shower. He denies any recent trauma and is otherwise completely well. There is no significant medical or surgical history, and he has a regular sexual partner. Observations are within normal limits. His abdomen is soft and non-tender with no signs of an inguinal hernia. A small, non-tender, palpable mass is felt just posterior and separate from the body of the right testicle. The left testicular exam is normal.

What is the most likely diagnosis?
notes:
Epididymal cyst is the most likely diagnosis. These are common in middle-aged men and feature a swelling posterior and separate from the body of the testicle. They are benign, and the diagnosis can be confirmed by ultrasound. Management is generally conservative.

Epididymitis will have features of infection such as pain, erythema, and fever. Urethral discharge can also be present. The infection may also involve the testes (epididymo-orchitis), causing unilateral testicular pain and swelling. Recommended treatment is a single IM dose of ceftriaxone 500mg plus oral doxycycline 100mg BD for 10-14 days.

Germ-cell tumour presents as a firm and typically painless lump on the testicle. They are the most common malignancy in younger males, but the incidence then decreases with age. Other risk factors include infertility, cryptorchidism, mumps orchitis, and Klinefelter syndrome. There may be associated hydrocele and gynaecomastia due to an increased oestrogen to androgen ratio.

Hydrocele is a collection of fluid within the tunica vaginalis (the membrane that surrounds the testes). It is common in neonates and will present as a large scrotal swelling. It is less common in adults but can occur if there is a recent history of testicular trauma or orchitis. Management is generally conservative.

Varicocele is an abnormal enlargement of the testicular veins that is classically felt as a 'bag of worms' within the scrotum. It is more common on the left side and can be associated with subfertility. Diagnosis can be confirmed on ultrasound with Doppler studies. Management is generally conservative unless the patient is having issues with pain or subfertility.

title: Epididymal cysts
body:
Epididymal cysts are the most common cause of scrotal swellings seen in primary care.

Features
  • separate from the body of the testicle
  • found posterior to the testicle

Associated conditions
  • polycystic kidney disease
  • cystic fibrosis
  • von Hippel-Lindau syndrome

Diagnosis may be confirmed by ultrasound
concept: An epididymal cyst is a cause of scrotal swelling which can be palpated as separate from the body of the testicle
media:
Understanding Epididymal Cysts
Zero To Finals - YouTube40

3685.concept_text: An epididymal cyst is a cause of scrotal swelling which can be palpated as separate from the body of the testicle
